div.p: Friday April 1. 1791. I have many time attempted? to keep a Journal of my transactions, but steady and? regular attention to one object, is more difficult than we? are ready to imagine; yet and I have always dropped the practice after a period of longer or of shorter duration. Yet it frequently happens that I wish to fix the fleeting reflection which originates in some transient occurrence, let me attempt once more an undertaking, which indolence has so often rendered abortive, and perhaps I may this Time be the more successful for avoiding the constraint of a regular and daily recurrence to my diary. Upon the present occasion I shall be contented with this introduction, and indeed have little to observe upon the present day, which I have spent altogether at my office.

Thursday April 7th. Since I wrote the foregoing lines I have not had a moment of Time to spare for adding any thing to them. Yet I have had nothing to do. Time slips unheeded away and yet upon looking back there is little to afford pleasure in the retrospect. My present situation is not over eligible: how to improve it is the subject which most employs my mind. I have much leisure upon my hands, and my own improvement seems to be the proper object of my pursuit.— This object I have frequently before me, but I do not write with facility, and what is worse, whenever I journalize, I soon grow disgusted with my own egotism.

Sunday April 3d: Tea at Mr: Breck’s. There was. Mrs:. . .rs and Miss Morgan. Mr: Elliot, Mr: Hallowell. Mr: W. Payne, T. Crafts S. C. Johonnot. and J. Callender. Miss Morgan comes I believe from Princeton in the Jerseys. she has past the winter in town. Has some relation to Doctor Stillman’s family, and lives with his daughters. Her countenance is pleasing, not very handsome, her manners very reserved, but not disagreeable. I have been several times in company with her, but there is something forbidding about her: I never heard her say a good thing, nor have I observed any thing remarkably amiable graceful in her demeanour. Yet let not this testimony pass, without adding that she has many enthusiastic admirers. Lowell thinks her a none-such, and of course all the females within the canonical degrees of affinity to him reecho the applause, which he bestows with great liberality, upon her. Lowell censures or commends with a vengeance and his Sisters and cousins are not without their share of the same failing. These people value themselves upon their strong feelings. Yet strong feelings are not becoming to the human species, and more especially to women.

lg.l: “Not to admire is all the art I know.”

div.p: And with this maxim (says a person of great authority in my mind) it is necessary to adopt another which is “not to despise.” There is no truth of which I am more convinced.— However, as Miss Morgan is so uninteresting upon the acquaintance which I have with her, perhaps it is best to let her for the present, rest in peace.
I had some conversation with Johonnot. He is going to Demarara, upon a speculation. He professes not to know himself what his object will be upon his arrival there, and I believe he says truly.

This speculation may possibly succeed, but if I know Johonnot, the greatest difficulty, which he will meet with in life will be the result of his own instability of character. He has not perseverance enough to be successful in scarcely any pursuit, for perhaps of all human qualities this of perseverance is in general the most useful.— He is easily discouraged, and indeed his opening in life has not been such as could satisfy a young man, of warm passions and a lively imagination.— He told me that he considered himself as unfortunate, and that he was determined if possible to run away from misfortune. His education he said had been principally in Europe; but there was a fundamental error, which had been the source of much unhappiness to him, and from which he was now recovered. He had been told in early youth, nay it had been instilled into his mind: with a cruel assiduity that he was born to great things; that his genius was extraordinary, his abilities commanding, and that he would undoubtedly come forward into the world like a phenomenon, and carry all before him.— This pernicious idea once implanted in his mind, had taken deep root in a soil perhaps too well calculated to produce spontaneously a weed of a similar nature. Just upon his return from Europe, he lost his Grandfather, Dr: Cooper, a man highly respected in this Country, and who might have been highly serviceable to him in promoting his introduction to the world. His father at the same period was totally ruined, and the disposition of the world was sufficiently prone to connect the character of the son with the failure of the father. He had himself in the course of a foreign education adopted habits of life, and manners, which were displeasing to his countrymen; and he was not perhaps so much attached to theirs as every man must be with those of the people with
with whom he lives in order to be happy. Instead of the applause and success which he had been taught to expect he found himself an unpopular character, with many enemies, and with nothing to boast of from Friendship.— To a man who had feelings he said this reverse in the real situation, of that which he had anticipated, must be painful; and he considered these circumstances as sufficient to authorise him in saying he was not unacquainted with adversity. He had given up all his extravagant fancies, and all his romantic expectations; he wished henceforth for no more than a decent and honorable maintenance, and to acquire that he was willing to leave his country and seek his fortune in more hospitable climes.— He spoke with feeling. He spoke with eloquence. I doubted whether his present determination were judicious, but I respected his principle, and my mind acknowledged the truth of his observations. Most heartily do I wish he may succeed; for his failings have been sufficiently punished, his Vanity sufficiently humbled, and I hope the errors of his disposition corrected— But His own principal endeavour henceforth ought to be to acquire perseverance, and fortitude, which is a virtue perhaps of more practical utility through life than active resolution, unrestrained by a cool and sober judgment.

I went with Callender and spent the remainder of the evening at Mr: Higginson’s. There were his daughters Sally and Barbara; his son Stephen, and Mr Fulton, a man who said nothing, and whom I scarcely saw.— Of these people more anon: I have at present no time.
At home 9 o’clock I found Mr: & Mrs. Smith and his Sister Betsey.— And I can write no more for I am heartily tired already.

There was an annular eclipse of the Sun this morning; I went upon Beacon Hill to see it, but the severity of a keen Northwester soon brought me down again.— Hurt my eyes much by observing this same Eclipse without a glass.

Monday April 4th: Walking down upon long wharf this morning with Crafts I met Dr: Woodbury, who delivered me the key of a trunk which I left at Philadelphia to be sent to me. Past the Evening at the Miss Amory’s.— The Company, Rebecca Amory, and Mary her Sister and a younger Sister. Two Miss Higginson’s Sally and Barbara. Two Miss Lowell’s Nancy and Sally, and Miss Talbot.— Men R. Codman, S. Higginson, and J. Callender. and J. Lowell.

The evening was dull. Miss Amory performed upon the Piano Forte, which was amusing; she sung, and sings well. Callender likewise and Mr: Codman sung. The latter has a very good voice.— But there was not much ease apparent in the Company. There was a formality, not unusual in parties of this kind, which favoured too much of restraint to allow much happiness to any one. I believe we were all relieved when we separated. Some of the Ladies rallied Callender upon his seriousness. This is allowable in polite companies, where there is any degree of familiarity; yet as such reproaches never fail to increase the failure itself, I do not think them perfectly consistent with politeness. It is the peculiar privilege of friendship in retirement to enquire into the reasons of low Spirits. In mixed companies it never should be done. It cannot dispel the gloom, and a benevolent disposition will never sport with dejection.

Rebecca Amory may be about 18. She is too robust in stature, & rather too irregular in feature to be perfectly beautiful. She has however a fine complection, a delicate skin, the roseate bloom of Health, and an eye sufficiently expressive to captivate, a man who is
is not systematically indifferent. Lowell she has thoroughly captivated. He has for these two years tendered his humble Services to her, and she receives them with pleasure. Nothing but fair prospects of Life seem at present to be wanting to complete the union— She is reserved in temper, though I believe candid & benevolent. There is a little hauteur that involuntarily hangs about her, it bars my sociability with her. In general I am not disposed to be familiarly acquainted, with an unmarried woman engaged to another man; indeed I know not the reason why, but instinctively I avoid such women much more than those who are already married; I have never examined the grounds of this disposition which results from habit rather than from reason; but Miss Amory independent of this circumstance has manners rather forbidding, and I feel not enough interested to wish to overcome the difficulties of approach. Lowell is assiduous: even a little jealous: perhaps this renders her rather more distant to others than she would naturally be.— More upon this subject I cannot say.

Mary Amory, her Sister is a year or two younger. By Nature, not much favoured, and as usual atones for her deficiency in point of beauty by the excellency of her disposition. She is good; but her goodness is not perhaps esteemed so much as it deserves, because she is not handsome, nor even graceful. Her manners are not rough; but they have not the nice and delicate polish, which render sometimes deformity itself amiable: neither has she any of that sprightliness of wit, that charming vivacity, which sometimes serves as a substitute for personal charms. She is too amiable to class among the insipids, and yet unless she has some qualities, which I have not discovered, (and my acquaintance with her is indeed very small) I know not in what other class she could claim a rank.

Sally Higginson is verging rapidly towards 25. Nay, I know not but what she has already attained that formidable period. She is not handsome; it is her misfortune; and a cruel misfortune it is to every woman of sense and feeling; say the Sentimentalists what they please. Yet Miss Higginson is much admired: every one speaks well of her. The cold approbation of rational Judgment is always in her favour. But the instinctive plaudit of sensibility is not for her. In truth she is rather too sensible. There is something in the very nature of mental abilities, which seems to be unbecoming in a female. But in addition to this Miss Higginson talks much; she always talks well but her conversation has is too judicious to be perfectly pleasing in such a constancy of continuation. The woman who talks a great deal is excusable only when she says many lively things; some witty, a few judicious and most of all extravagant or without much meaning. Such in general is the character of the most interesting coquettes. And the general aversion to coquette’s proceeds on the part of men principally from fear; on that of women always from envy. Miss Higginson sometimes laughs. I know not any thing that a sensible woman should attend to with more nicety, than her manner of laughing. Indeed if a Lady can suppress it altogether, she will find that a smile beaming forth good nature and benevolence is a much more captivating substitute. The loud laugh is unsufferable. The giggle is contemptible. The titter is ill-bred, and the sneer though sometimes to be admitted must be used with infinite caution. The lovely smile, expressive sometimes of pleasure, sometimes of complacency, and always of innocence seems to be the only native inhabitant of the female face. Yet Miss Higginson laughs. Nay her laugh is not even studied— It seems to be but the clumsy expression of a painful
convulsion. I wish some of her friends would hint to her the improvement which she could easily acquire. Her goodness of disposition, her uncommon prudence and discretion are the theme on which her friends dwell with peculiar pleasure. These are qualifications highly valuable, and too rarely found among our young Ladies. But alas! my taste is naturally depraved. Prudence and Discretion never will possess the peculiar charm for me. I revere them as virtues; I should be sorry to find them strangers to the object of my Affections. Yet freely must I confess it, never can they rouse those affections, never can they deeply interest them. Should my Heart ever yield itself to the voice of Love, I hope my Judgment will approve, though it must never pretend to direct the Passion.

Tuesday April 5th: Spent the Evening again at Mr: Higginson’s. Two Miss Lowell’s, two Miss Russell’s, Miss Talbot, and Miss Palfrey, and Miss R. Amory. Theodore Lincoln. T. Crafts. J. Lowell. J. Blake. J. Callender; and a Mr: Bliss from St: John’s. The evening was tolerably pleasant. The conversation rather general, sometimes Sentimental. J. Lowell got hold of Lavater’s maxims, read off several of them and expounded them with self complacency and a full conviction of his own ingenuity. Yet methinks I could willingly submit to all the disgust occasioned by such cool and immovable self-sufficiency, to derive the advantages which that confidence offers for success in the world. I am not fully satisfied upon this point in Speculation, and I defer my determination until experience shall give me a more extensive ground to stand upon. But to return to Lavater’s maxims.— We sat in a kind of semicircle the circumference of which came about to the middle
middle of the Room. There was a table out of the bounds of the circle upon which stood a couple of candles. Lowell had got his Lavater, and stood by the side of the table, bending himself towards the light, to read a maxim. “A great woman not imperious”—he stopp’d, held his book open in his left hand, and turning towards us to mention instances, as he named them raised his right hand upwards & stretch’d out his fore-finger, as a summons for our attention—“Mrs Knox”—“Mrs Bingham.” It was silly, but I was much more so. “Your example fails you” said I “no woman can less deserve the imputation of being imperious than Mrs: Bingham.” I speak only said Lowell “of the character which common Fame gives her. I have not been to the southward Mr. Adams.”— Never was poor Devil more deficient in point of repartee than I am. The reflection fell with its full weight and I had no address to throw it back upon his shoulders, which I certainly did not want inclination to do, and to which he was very open. I was Silent; it was the only weapon left me, and he proceeded in his Lecture.— What could tempt me to say any thing about Mrs: Bingham, as if I meant to display an acquaintance with her I know not. It might be a lurking Vanity imperceptible to myself; though there are few persons of whose acquaintance I have less reason to be vain, or whose acquaintance I less value.— I myself think it was simply an intention to deny the truth of the aphorism itself, which naturally led me to deny the illustration. In my unnecessary zeal, I did not consider, the inference which malignity might naturally draw, and in such a blundering manner drew upon myself the implied sarcasm, contained in the Latter clause of his speech.

Crafts was urged to sing. he refused; and persisted though unreasonably urged; Callender sung one or two songs & then retired complaining of an headach. We separated between ten and eleven and I came home with Crafts.

Barbara Higginson, is in her 18th: year. Her complexion dark but clear; her eyes black and expressive; hair black; curled in beautiful ringlets, and of as fine a texture as any that I ever beheld. She is tall; tolerably well formed, though not perfect in the proportions of elegant shapes— She should wear an hoop. The features of her face are regularly handsome; her eye-brows beautifully arched, her teeth good, and in the estimation of many, is the handsomest woman in Boston. Yet Young, and beautiful as she is, there is yet a charm which she does not possess. Every one admires her, as he would admire the Venus de Medecis— It is lovely, but it is a statue. Her manners are not soft; she laughs more, and her laugh is more clumsy than that of her Sister. Indeed she laughs often somewhat loud, when the cause of her merriment in the opinion of her companions is scarcely adequate to raise a smile. She is not very lively; not very well informed even for her age, and of course her conversation does not support the interest to which her personal superiority at first sight entitles her. She entertains very strong prepossessions for or against the persons with whom she is acquainted, and perhaps the rapidity of youthful decision does not allow her to examine well the grounds of those judgments, which are so energetic. To become thoroughly pleasing the asperities of her character and manners ought considerably to be softened: those who are more acquainted with her would be better enabled than I am, whether there are
not likewise asperities of disposition which require correction.— Of the rest of this company more occasionally.

Sunday April 10th: After attending upon public worship, I went to take tea at Mr: Foster’s, and found there a company somewhat numerous. Mrs: Otis. Miss Bethune, Miss Gray (English) Miss Morgan, and Miss Lucy Breck: besides Mr: Foster’s twin daughters Grace and Mary. Mr: John Amory, D. Sargeant Mr Barton, Mr: Muller, Mr. W. Payne. J. Cutler, N. Frazier. T. Crafts. Major Otis, and J. Callender.

The room was so full that I did not get a very favourable seat, and had no opportunity of conversing any of the Ladies. I had however some conversation with Mr: Cutler, and some with D. Sargeant, who has been reading Mr: Burke’s late Pamphlet upon the revolution in France. he made some judicious remarks upon the subject and appeared to agree in the opinion which I had entertained of the Work. Between 8 and 9 I came away with Callender, who exclaimed against the party as soon as we came out of the house. It was too large. There was no enjoyment: where so many people were together. Those Miss Foster’s he said were very handsome, and very agreeable; but they were too much of fine women for him. There is a display of elegance and of fashion about them; which is really disadvantageous to them. I am pleased to see even a little decent weakness in the manners of a woman. This kind of state, like gravity is of the very essence of dissimulation. Where it is adopted, and pursued, you might see a woman an hundred times without seeing a single characteristic trait— It is not pleasing for it puts every one upon his guard— A woman of sense, will show something amiable even to the greatest stranger. There is a natural communication between the heart and the manners; and this professed elegance always destroys it.— Characters of this kind
kind always appear to wear a mask; and we feel ourselves of course put on our guard against them.—
